chapters.content:
Chapter 1 covers boiler components and draft control devices for hydronic heating systems. Wet-base boiler sections show fire brick and refractory which are heat-resistant cement-like materials used to retain heat in chamber and protect metal enclosing combustion chamber. These materials form "dry" sections of combustion chambers.

Flue-gas passages from heat exchanger carry heat from combustion process to water-filled portion of boiler. Some boilers have vertical flue passages while others horizontal. Generally speaking, greater number of flue passes results in greater heat transfer to boiler water. Some boiler flue passes may include spiral-shaped baffles or "turbulators" that act to increase heat transfer by inducing turbulence and slowing passage of exhaust gases.

Vertical passages: in boiler with vertical passages, hot flue gas rises from combustion chamber transferring heat to water-filled tubes or boiler sections as passes around them once before exiting flue. This is common style for atmospheric or natural-draft-style boilers where flue passes allow buoyancy venting of hot products of combustion.

Horizontal passages: in boiler with horizontal passages, hot flue gas directed through horizontal openings between water-filled sections or tubes in boiler, increasing travel time for flue gases and allowing more efficient heat transfer. In some boilers flue gas must make several passes in each direction before exiting flue.

Draft-control devices: achieving efficiency in combustion requires controlling amount and force of draft. Boilers use various methods to control rate of draft. Consequences of different drafts: too strong draft draws in too much combustion air reducing time for heat transfer; too weak draft smothers flame and reduces combustion efficiency. Draft-control devices essential component in venting system. Different types depend on type of burner and boiler: draft hoods (or draft diverters) and barometric dampers (or draft regulators).

Draft hood: some domestic gas boilers are atmospheric type and require neutral overfire draft in combustion chamber. In this context draft hood ensures neutral pressure maintained over fire. By allowing dilution air into venting system, draft hood lowers temperature of flue gases which also prevents hot gases from inducing negative pressure. When there is no draft, backdraft, or blockage beyond draft hood, flue gases exit draft hood instead of entering appliance (known as "spillage"). Hood or diverter either built into gas appliance or part of vent connector; should never be altered or modified.

Barometric dampers: used on appliances operating with controlled negative overfire draft in combustion chamber. This type of draft control used when venting system provides negative draw on combustion chamber to remove flue gases. Double-acting barometric damper can open both inward and outward: opening inward to regulate dilution air, opening outward to relieve down-draft and spillage.

Dilution air: when vent draw increases, atmospheric pressure on outside of damper pushes against gate allowing in extra dilution air to reduce draft draw. Downdraft: if pressure increases inside venting system, gate swings out to relieve downdraft. Spillage: in event of blockage in venting system, gate swings out to allow spillage.

Vent and flue dampers: dampers control flow of flue gases and may be useful for preventing escape of heat through venting system. Three common types: automatic vent dampers, thermally actuated vent dampers, flue dampers.

Automatic vent dampers: electrically activated automatic vent dampers prevent heat from escaping through boiler's venting system when boiler not being fired. Damper installed in boiler venting system downstream of draft-control device and consists of tubular casing, damper blade, and electric motor-driven actuator. Damper blade normally in closed position blocking vent. Vent damper actuator has proving switch interlocked with thermostat controlling boiler burner. When call for heat vent damper opens automatically to ensure passage of flue gases. Burner does not operate until vent fully open and vent remains open until burner shuts down. Automatic vent dampers located downstream of draft hood relief openings.

Thermally actuated vent dampers: operate in response to temperature of flue gases. When flue-gas temperature rises damper blades (bimetal leaf) open to allow passage of flue gases out of venting system. After burner shut down and temperature of flue decreases damper blades close. Blades come with small slots allowing minimum airflow through vent to permit safe startup. Thermally actuated vent dampers located downstream of draft-hood relief openings.

Flue dampers: movable plate designed to regulate amount of flow or draft that can pass through boiler's flue. Flue dampers can either be manually adjusted or automatically open and close. Automatic flue dampers must either be interlocked (to automatically close off supply of gas to appliance) or provided with means to ensure damper fails in fully open position in event of motor failure. Flue dampers located upstream of any draft-hood relief openings.

Key concepts: pressurizing system prevents water in hydronic heating system from boiling into steam when system operating above atmospheric boiling temperature. Aquastat considered part of hydronic control system. Backflow preventer installed to protect potable water connections to boiler from cross-contamination with toxic substances or non-potable boiler water. Advantages of hydronic heating system include quiet operation, increased comfort, less air stratification (not fast reaction time). Input of 400 MBtu/h or greater requires LWCO for hot water boiler. Tapered push-nipples used to connect multiple cast-iron boiler sections into boiler block assembly. Copper fin tube boilers can be used to directly heat domestic water. If flue gas combustion products cooled below dew point, condensation is result. Steel water-tube boilers commonly used for production of hot water or steam. To prevent thermal stress damage, steel water tube type boiler requires constant water circulation during firing. Condensing boilers typically made from stainless steel. For atmospheric boilers, spillage explains result if no draft, backdraft, or blockage in venting system beyond draft hood. Automatic vent damper actuator has proving switch to control boiler's burner.

chapters.content:
Chapter 2 covers hydronic distribution systems and control systems. Many different distribution systems used in hydronic heating. This Chapter describes piping systems and controls utilized for distribution systems and includes examples of control strategies. Gas technician/fitter must also have clear understanding of system filling and purging methods and air elimination devices since gas fitters/technicians start up boiler-heated hydronic systems.

Hydronic water-heating distribution systems classified according to design of piping layout and type of heat distribution units employed. Many different types including single-series circuit, one-pipe systems, two-pipe systems, and radiant-floor heating.

Single series circuit (series loop system): simplest hydronic distribution system is series loop. This type of system (often controlled by single room or area thermostat) appropriate for applications where all rooms experience similar heating load changes in response to changes in outdoor conditions. In series system heat-distributing units connected so all water flowing through each circuit passes through each component in circuit. Single pipe (or main) helps convey hot water from boiler to heating units. Main directly connects each heating unit in series to one another. Large system may be composed of two or more separate series circuits, with each circuit running from boiler outlet to boiler return.

Critical that water flow sufficient to prevent cooling at end of loop. One advantage of series system is requires less pipe and fittings than parallel (two-pipe) system. Heat input to building with single-series circuit regulated based on temperature at location of one thermostat (which can lead to overheating or underheating of rooms when thermostat does not accurately represent temperature across different rooms). For this reason important to size each heating unit in this type of system for load of room(s) it services and adjust to water temperature at each unit's location in circuit.

Single-circuit systems may also consist of combination of heating units such as panel radiators and fan-coil units. Series circuits with one or more heating units having high-flow resistance characteristics may experience problems. For example, heating unit such as fan coil with high-flow resistance can excessively reduce flow rate through rest of system limiting system's total heat output. Zone control in single-series circuit limited to adjusting control devices on individual heating units. For example, closing dampers on enclosure of finned-tube baseboard unit reduces its heat output by about 40%. Use of fan-coil unit can reduce speed of blower to limit heat output. Act of regular manual adjustments to individual units is response to changing heat load conditions.

One-pipe Monoflo® system: has one continuous pipe or main running from boiler supply outlet(s) back to boiler return inlet(s). Two smaller pipes (supply and return branches) connect each heating unit to main pipe. One-pipe diverter tee fittings installed in main where branches connect to it. These special fittings (often called Monoflo® tees) divert portion of main water flow into heating unit supply pipes. Depending on location of heat transfer unit in relation to main, there is either one or two Monoflo® tees used. After passing through heating unit, water flows out unit's return pipe and diverted back into main. System with two or more circuits called multiple-circuit one-pipe Monoflo® system.

Advantages of one pipe: fewer piping requirements, valves and diverter tees can control flow to each heating unit. Disadvantages: one-pipe system not suitable for high head-loss heat transfer units, total heat load typically limited to 50 000 to 60 000 Btu/h per circuit.

Diverter tee applications: diverter tees divert some water from main piping through heating unit on branch circuit. Installation of diverter tees can be individual or in pairs. With use of two diverter tees, greater pressure difference created across branch circuit induces higher flow rate in branch. Single diverter-tee installations often adequate for low-resistance heating units such as short runs of finned-tube baseboard or panel radiator. Pair of diverter tees may be required for fan coils or other units with higher-flow resistances. In dual diverter-tee installation, should be at least 1 ft of pipe between tees. This piping arrangement allows partial dissipation of any flow turbulence created by first tee before entering second tee.

Control valve helps control flow rate through heating unit branch circuit. Control valve may be manually adjusted globe or angle valve installed adjacent to unit or built into it. Manual control valves of this type may require regular adjustments to maintain constant room temperature during changing heat load conditions. Non-electric thermostatic radiator valve can be useful for automatic control.

Two-pipe systems: has one main pipe to convey hot water from boiler to heating units and second pipe to return cooled water from heating units back to boiler. Advantage of two-pipe system is simple individual control of each heating unit. Two types: direct return and reverse return.

Direct return: in direct-return two-pipe hydronic system water from heating units returns to boiler via shortest practical path (known as "first-fed, first-return"). Length of circuit and resistance to flow through units close to boiler significantly less than for units farther away which can cause uneven system flow rates. For this reason use of system-balancing valves to create additional friction in shorter circuits is must.

Reverse return: in reverse-return two-pipe hydronic system, heating units connected to return main in reverse order they are connected to supply main. This arrangement ensures circuit length and flow resistance through each heating unit approximately equal which helps reduce system-balancing problems. Heating unit closest to heat source (on supply main) is farthest from heat source on return main. Conversely farthest heating unit from heat source on supply main is also closest on return (known as "first-fed, last-return"). This arrangement overcomes most flow-balancing problems associated with parallel direct-return systems particularly when all heating units have similar flow resistances.

Two-pipe system requires different sizes of pipe in certain parts of system. For example, size of supply main piping progressively smaller farther away from heat source, while return main piping progressively larger closer to heat source. Optimum arrangement for parallel reverse-return system is to route supply and return mains around perimeter of zone being heated. If reverse-return hydronic system designed and sized correctly, much easier to balance than direct-return system. However these systems not "self-balancing". Every system requires flow balancing to ensure each circuit within distribution system achieving its design flow rates.

Primary/Secondary systems: usually consists of primary loop that delivers heated water to one or more secondary circuits. Secondary circuits typically connected to primary loop using pairs of closely spaced tees. Little pressure drop exists between pair of closely spaced tees which means flow along primary loop has little tendency to induce flow within secondary circuit. Since virtually no pressure differential between tees, flow less likely to develop in secondary circuit even though passed through tees in primary circuit. Closely spaced tees provide "hydraulic separation" between primary circuit and each secondary circuits which provides stable on/off flow control in multiple independently controlled circuits each having own circulator. Flow in secondary circuit only occurs when its own "secondary circulator" turned on. Secondary circulator draws heated water from primary loop, sends through secondary circuit, and returns cooler flow downstream of heat emitters back to primary loop.

Commonly closely spaced tees arranged in series one set after another along primary loop. Parallel primary loop configuration also possible but requires more complex piping arrangement. If heat source has low flow resistance usually piped as part of primary loop. However if heat source has higher flow resistance usually provided with own circulator and connected to primary loop using set of closely spaced tees.

Radiant heating (radiant panels): warm water circulates through tubing embedded in or secured to flooring material. Most heat transferred to flooring from warm water radiates upwards into room. Small portion of heat lost through bottom and edges of floor. Radiant systems may be attached to underside of wood subflooring or embedded in thin layer of gypcrete topping poured over subfloor. Radiant tubing can also be installed in walls and ceilings.

Another common method: tubing embedded in concrete structural slab. Use of various layout patterns acceptable depending on floor material used and heat loss of room (patterns include single wall serpentine, double wall serpentine, counter flow spiral). When slab placed directly on grade, underside and edges of slab must be well insulated. Hydronic system tubing typically attached to metal bars or wire mesh installed in slab for reinforcement. Most common tubing for hydronic in-floor heating systems is cross-linked polyethylene (PEX) with oxygen barrier or cross-linked polyethylene/aluminum/cross-linked polyethylene (PEX/AL/PEX). Gas technicians/fitters have tried various other piping materials in past but most had issues with oxygen diffusion leading to system failures.

Terminology: Backflow is reversal of normal direction of flow. Free air is air away from shielding structures, vegetation, or other obstructions that may interfere with accurate temperature sensing. Gallons per minute (gpm) is measure of how many gallons of liquid flow each minute (also known as flow rate). Zoning is division of hydronic heating system into two or more independently controlled distribution circuits.

topics: Point of no pressure change (point at which expansion tank attached to system piping)
At point of no pressure change system remains at system static pressure
Prevents additional air and water from being drawn into system
Circulator can effectively do job of developing pressure to move water through system
Effect of circulator location on system pressure
Best place to install primary circulating pump in hydronic system
Immediately upstream of expansion tank keeps system at static pressure
Prevents pressure drops that could draw air into system
Rotating piece of centrifugal pump called impeller
Effect of increasing rpm of centrifugal pump: more pressure and more flow
Area of lowest pressure within centrifugal circulator is impeller eye
Head is pressure difference pump can produce between inlet and outlet ports
Head measured in feet of head water column (ft. hd. w.c.)
Flow rate calculation: US gpm = System heat loss (Btu/h) ÷ [Temperature drop (°F) × 500]
For 40 000 Btu/h with 30 °F temperature drop: 40 000 ÷ (30 × 500) = 2.67 US gpm
Installing two centrifugal pumps in series doubles pressure
Installing two centrifugal pumps in parallel doubles flow
When shut-off valve closed downstream of centrifugal circulator, current draw decreases
Pump mounting and piping connections
Most circulators for residential and small commercial designed to be mounted with pump shaft in horizontal position
Eliminates thrust loads on pump bearings caused by weight of rotor and impeller
Must orient pump in correct direction of fluid flow (arrow on volute indicates direction)
Can install pump with arrow pointing up, down, or horizontally as long as pump shaft horizontal
System piping cannot be relied upon to support circulator unless circulator light and piping well supported
Vibration-absorbing mounts and couplings recommended
When replacing pump coupler, check pump shaft to make sure not out of alignment
Misalignment of pump shaft can cause premature coupler failure
Pump-bearing assemblies contain oil reservoirs, must not install in way that allows oil to drain from bearing assembly
Header mounting (some multi-zone installations require mounting circulators on common header assembly)
Header usually made of steel or iron pipe strong enough to support weight of circulators
Bending effect of assembly puts stress on connection to boiler
Should support or suspend end of header assembly farthest from boiler
Piping connections (most circulators designed to be connected to piping with bolted flanges)
Flange-mounting makes removal of circulators from system easier for servicing
One side of flanged joint part of volute of pump, other side threaded onto piping
O-ring or gasket compressed between flange faces forms watertight seal
Isolation flange allows unbolting and removal of circulator with no loss of fluid
Has built-in ball valve that can open or close with screwdriver
Another mounting method: standard flanges and gate valve or ball valve in piping on each side of pump
Some small circulators connected to piping by tail piece (half-union) threading directly onto pump volute
Other small circulators soldered directly to copper tubing system distribution lines
Pump head (height to which pump can lift and maintain column of water)
Pressure difference pump can produce between inlet and discharge ports
Indication of mechanical energy imparted by pump to fluid being pumped
Energy imparted to fluid results in increased flow rate (kinetic energy) or increased pressure (potential energy)
In hydronic systems flow rate and flow velocity of fluids entering pump always equal to those leaving pump
Mechanical energy (via pump head) produces increase in fluid pressure between inlet and discharge ports
Increase inversely proportional to flow rate through pump and density of fluid
As flow rate increases, pressure difference across pump decreases
Pump head expressed in units of feet of head: Head = ft•lb/lb = energy/lb = ft
Basic principles: design water temperature drop, system flow rate, system pressure loss (resistance)
Pump curves, increasing flow and pressure, pump motor current draw, thermal balancing
Design water temperature drop: difference between water temperature at point where leaves boiler and point where returns
Recommended temperature drop depends on type of terminal unit and manufacturer rating
Series loop system baseboard or commercial fin-tube boiler units: up to 50 °F (28 °C)
Two-pipe systems cast-iron radiators: up to 30 °F (17 °C)
Convectors: 10 to 30 °F (6 to 17 °C) depending on manufacturer ratings
Unit heaters: up to 50 °F (28 °C) on condition minimum flow rates maintained
System flow rate calculation Method 1: Flow rate (US gpm) = System heat loss (Btu/h) ÷ [Temperature drop (°F) × 500]
Example: building heat loss 35 000 Btu/h, design temperature drop 20 °F: 35 000 ÷ (20 × 500) = 3.5 gpm
System pressure loss (resistance): total pressure loss or system resistance is sum of resistances of all flow-restricting components
Resistance losses of components and piping listed in manufacturer specifications and trade reference manuals
Increasing flow and pressure: can install circulators in pairs
Two pumps of same size installed in series doubles system pressure
Two pumps of same size installed in parallel doubles system flow rate
Pump curves: published by manufacturers are basic pump selection tool
Works in combination with system resistance curve to determine which circulator best matches system head and flow requirements
Procedure: determine desired flow rate based on heat required, determine head loss at required flow rate using system resistance curve
Plot operating point representing desired flow rate and head loss at that rate on same axes as pump curve
Circulator should have between 10 and 20% extra head capacity above calculated head loss at desired flow rate
Extra margin necessary to ensure system requirements still met if installation requires more piping than original design
Pump curve should intersect system curve in or near area of highest pump efficiency
Pump's highest efficiency region usually close to knee of its curve
Current draw on circulator motor: larger piping in system increases current draw on motor
Shutting off valve on system supply (specifically pump discharge side) decreases current draw on motor
Thermal balancer: many low-mass boilers require minimum circulation to prevent kettling (boiling) in heat exchanger
When aquastat shuts burner and pump off after lengthy firing period, may be considerable residual heat buildup
With no circulation to dissipate it, residual heat may be sufficient to cause high-limit aquastat to open
Thermal balancer (or pump delay) is snap-action single-pole double-throw relay

Chapter 3 covers circulators and pump operation in hydronic heating systems. Point of no pressure change refers to point at which expansion tank attached to system piping. At this point system remains at system static pressure which prevents additional air and water from being drawn into system. Circulator can then effectively do its job of developing pressure to move water through system.

Effect of circulator location on system pressure: best place to install primary circulating pump in hydronic system is immediately upstream of expansion tank. This keeps system at static pressure and prevents pressure drops that could draw air into system. At point of no pressure change, when pump off system at 12 psi (84 kPa), when pump on pressure stays same there. Different configurations show pressure changes: upstream installation can cause pressure to drop to 6 psi (42 kPa) in some areas, downstream installation can increase pressure to 18 psi (126 kPa) in some areas.

Rotating piece of centrifugal pump called impeller. Effect of increasing rpm of centrifugal pump is more pressure and more flow. Area of lowest pressure within centrifugal circulator is impeller eye. Head is pressure difference pump can produce between its inlet and outlet ports. Head measured in feet of head water column (ft. hd. w.c.).

Flow rate calculations: US gpm = System heat loss (Btu/h) ÷ [Temperature drop (°F) × 500]. For example, to supply 40 000 Btu/h with design temperature drop of 30 °F: 40 000 ÷ (30 × 500) = 2.67 US gpm. Installing two centrifugal pumps in series doubles pressure. Installing two centrifugal pumps in parallel doubles flow. When shut-off valve closed downstream of centrifugal circulator, current draw decreases.

Pump mounting and piping connections: most circulators for residential and small commercial systems designed to be mounted with pump shaft in horizontal position. This configuration eliminates thrust loads on pump bearings caused by weight of rotor and impeller. Must orient pump in correct direction of fluid flow (arrow on volute indicates direction of flow). Can install pump with arrow pointing up, down, or horizontally as long as pump shaft horizontal.

System piping cannot be relied upon to support circulator unless circulator light and piping well supported. Vibration-absorbing mounts and couplings recommended for installations where circulator can transmit vibrations to building through piping. When replacing pump coupler, check pump shaft to make sure not out of alignment. Misalignment of pump shaft can cause premature coupler failure. Also pump-bearing assemblies contain oil reservoirs and must not install them in any way that allows oil to drain from bearing assembly.

Header mounting: some multi-zone installations require mounting of circulators on common header assembly. Header usually made of steel or iron pipe strong enough to support weight of circulators. However bending effect of assembly puts great deal of stress on its connection to boiler. For this reason should support or suspend end of header assembly farthest from boiler.

Piping connections: most circulators designed to be connected to piping with bolted flanges. Flange-mounting makes removal of circulators from system easier for servicing. One side of flanged joint is part of volute of pump and other side threaded onto piping. O-ring or gasket compressed between flange faces forms watertight seal. Isolation flange allows unbolting and removal of circulator from system with no loss of fluid other than what left in pump volute. This flange design has built-in ball valve that can open or close with screwdriver. When ball valves closed can remove circulator. Another mounting method allowing isolation of circulator is use of standard flanges and gate valve or ball valve in piping on each side of pump. Some small circulators connected to piping by means of tail piece (half-union) which threads directly onto pump volute. Other small circulators soldered directly to copper tubing system distribution lines.

Pump head: can define pump head as height to which pump can lift and maintain column of water, pressure difference pump can produce between its inlet and discharge ports, and indication of mechanical energy imparted by pump to fluid being pumped. Energy imparted to fluid results in increased flow rate (via kinetic energy) or increased pressure (via potential energy). In hydronic systems flow rate and flow velocity of fluids entering pump always equal to those leaving pump. In this case mechanical energy (via pump head) produces increase in fluid pressure between inlet and discharge ports of pump. Increase inversely proportional to flow rate through pump and density of fluid: as flow rate increases pressure difference across pump decreases. Pump head expressed in units of feet of head derived from equation: Head = ft•lb/lb = energy/lb = ft. Since ft•lb measure of energy, pump head can be described as mechanical energy added per lb of fluid.

Basic principles to consider when selecting and installing circulators: design water temperature drop, system flow rate, system pressure loss (resistance), pump curves, increasing flow and pressure, pump motor current draw, thermal balancing.

Design water temperature drop: difference between water temperature at point where leaves boiler and point where returns. Recommended temperature drop depends on type of terminal unit used and manufacturer rating. Series loop system baseboard or commercial fin-tube boiler units up to 50 °F (28 °C). Two-pipe systems cast-iron radiators up to 30 °F (17 °C), convectors 10 to 30 °F (6 to 17 °C) depending on manufacturer ratings, unit heaters up to 50 °F (28 °C) on condition minimum flow rates maintained.

System flow rate calculation Method 1: to size pump using performance curve, first calculate system flow rate using formula. Imperial: Flow rate (US gpm) = System heat loss (Btu/h) ÷ [Temperature drop (°F) × 500]. Metric: Flow rate (L/s) = System heat loss (kW) ÷ [Temperature drop (°C) × 4.2]. Example: building with heat loss 35 000 Btu/h, design temperature drop 20 °F. Accordingly pump must be capable of flow rate 3.5 gpm: 35 000 ÷ (20 × 500) = 3.5 gpm.

System pressure loss (resistance): total pressure loss or system resistance is sum of resistances of all flow-restricting components of system. Resistance losses of components and piping listed in manufacturer specifications and trade reference manuals.

Increasing flow and pressure: can install circulators in pairs to increase flow rate and pressure in hydronic system. Two pumps of same size installed in series double system pressure. Two pumps of same size installed in parallel double system flow rate.

Pump curves: pump curves published by manufacturers are basic pump selection tool. Works in combination with system resistance curve to determine which circulator best matches system head and flow requirements. Procedure: determine desired flow rate based on heat required by system's heating units (system heat loss), determine head loss of system at required flow rate using system resistance curve (use system circuit or loop with highest resistance based on manufacturer data), plot point (operating point) representing desired flow rate and head loss at that rate on same set of axes as pump curve, circulator should have between 10 and 20% extra head capacity above calculated head loss at desired flow rate (extra margin necessary to ensure system requirements still met if installation requires more piping and other flow-restricting components than original design specified), pump curve should intersect system curve in or near area of highest pump efficiency (pump's highest efficiency region usually close to knee of its curve).

Example shows how performance curves of two pumps compared to establish suitability. If system has head loss of 10.65 and requires flow rate of 3.5 gpm, operating point plotted on pump performance curve. When comparing performance curves of Pump 1 and Pump 2, can see Pump 2 is only suitable pump for application.

Current draw on circulator motor: two conditions affect current draw on pump motor. Larger piping in system increases current draw on motor. Shutting off valve on system supply (specifically pump discharge side) decreases current draw on motor.

Thermal balancer: many low-mass boilers require minimum circulation to prevent kettling (boiling) in heat exchanger. In many installations aquastat helps control burner and circulation pump operation. When aquastat shuts burner and pump off after lengthy firing period, may be considerable residual heat buildup in boiler. With no circulation in system to dissipate it, residual heat may be sufficient to cause high-limit aquastat to open. Thermal balancer (or pump delay) is snap-action single-pole double-throw relay which operates as follows. Thermal balancer prevents residual boiler heat from tripping high-limit aquastat by delaying circulator shut-off for 60 to 90 sec after burner shut-off. This margin of time allows extended period of heat transfer in exchanger, recovering residual boiler heat for heating purposes and balancing temperature in system with that of boiler.

When selecting thermal balancer important to ensure voltage and current ratings compatible with pump and other system components and it is approved for type of application intended. Newer control systems have integrated electronic system including all functions on same control board.

Balancer operation: during normal operation and call for heat (aquastat switch closed), pump energized by current passing through NC (normally closed) contacts. Gas valve and resistor also energized. Resistor heats up and after 60 to 90 sec causes NO (normally open) contacts to close and NC contacts to open. When aquastat switch opens both resistor and valve de-energized. Current continues to flow through NO contacts until such time as resistor cools (60 to 90 sec) causing NO contacts to open and NC contacts to close.

Chapter 4 covers control systems and troubleshooting for hydronic heating systems. Wiring diagram and ladder diagram for typical residential hydronic heating system shows L1 and N (120 V AC supply), boiler high limit, boiler operating limit (aquastats), boiler gas valve, room thermostat, zone valve (typical) with end-switch and motor, system pump, SPST relay, primary relay/transformer, circuit breaker, and service switch. 24 V transformer, 24 V AC secondary, and 120 volt AC supply circuits shown.

Wiring diagrams and sequence of operations: wiring and ladder diagrams useful for identifying operating sequence of hydronic system components and controls. These drawings supplied by equipment manufacturers work as installation guides for field wiring external system controls. May also be used to analyze and troubleshoot service problems.

Sequence of operations: circuit breaker in electrical distribution panel of building protects 120 V supply line. Can use service switch connected to 120 V circuit to turn electrical power to system on and off. Circulation pump wired across 120 V supply and turned on and off by action of SPST relay (primary relay). Action of zone valves controls primary relay.

Sequence of operations for control system follows: with circuit breaker and service switch closed, 120 V supply energizes 24 V ac transformer. On demand for heat from particular zone, room or zone thermostat closes and 24 V supplied from Terminal R to open zone valve. Some zone valves contain end switch (switch activated by opening of zone valve). When zone valve opens its end switch closes and 24 V from Terminal R supplied to Terminal G to actuate primary relay. This closes circuit that energizes pump circuit and burners. If aquastat and any other burner interlocks closed, automatic burner gas valve energized. Gas valve opens and gas flows into burner where it is ignited to heat water in boiler.

Analyzing and identifying control malfunctions: gas technician/fitter should be familiar with following potential issues causing malfunctioning of hydronic systems: circulator problems, boiler problems, mechanical problems.

Circulator problems specific to hydronic systems include system resistance and flow rate, and heat output and temperature difference. System resistance and flow rate: as resistance increases in system, pressure increases and flow rate decreases. Excessive resistance in system caused by scaling or other restrictions causes pump to work harder to maintain flow. Too much resistance in system reduces flow rate to point where system efficiency affected. Flow rate can also be too slow if pump motor does not have sufficient horsepower and rpm to maintain effective flow rate. To maintain proper flow rate required to select pump with adequate horsepower and rpm.

Heat output and temperature difference: boiler heat output and temperature difference between supply and return water affect pump performance. Circulating pump must be able to maintain flow rate sufficient to meet heat output and temperature differential of appliance and system. Calculate pump capacity: one Btu required to raise temperature of 1 lb of water by 1 °F, one US gallon water weighs 8.33 lb.

Calculating boiler output rate: Imperial formula Boiler output (Btu/h) ÷ I = 8.33 lb (ΔT) 60 minutes ÷ I = 500 (ΔT). Metric formula Boiler output (kW) ÷ I = 0.263 (ΔT) ÷ I = 500 (ΔT). Example: number of Btu/h required to maintain 20 °F temperature differential calculated as Boiler output (Btu/h) ÷ I = 500 × 20 ÷ I = 10 000 (Btu/h).

Calculating flow rate: Imperial formula Flow rate (US gpm) ÷ I = Boiler output (Btu/h) ÷ (500)ΔT. Metric formula Flow rate (L/s) ÷ I = Boiler output (kW) ÷ (4.19)ΔT. Example: system with 250 000 Btu/h output and system temperature differential 20 °F requires pump that can maintain flow rate 25 US gpm: 250 000 ÷ (500 × 20) = 25 US gpm.

Boiler problems: following conditions can result from boiler system malfunctions: carbonizing, condensation, corrosion, liming, underfiring and overfiring.

Carbonizing: flame impingement (resulting from too long burner flame or excessive water flow in fin-tube boilers) primarily causes carbonizing or sooting on heat-source surfaces. Also keep in mind: yellow tipping of burner flames can result from incorrect primary air adjustment, scale or lint can block burner's ports, incorrect burner port loading (or input) can lead to uneven combustion.

Condensation: condensation in combustion chamber of boiler usually occurs because of low flue-gas temperatures. Possible causes of low flue-gas temperatures: undersized or underfired boiler, excessive water flow, use of night setback thermostat, large-volume radiation equipment. Condensing-type boiler specially designed to take advantage of condensing gases and should not be confused with non-condensing applications.

Corrosion: internal corrosion may result from low flue-gas temperatures or air in system causing oxidation (rusting). Air can enter system in one of two ways: through boiler make-up water or through leaks in system. To reduce air infiltration equip system with adequate air-venting devices and check for leaks regularly. Corrosive chemicals in combustion air such as solvents, paint thinners, bleaches, chlorine, or fluorine vapours can cause external corrosion. Chlorine and fluorine present in chemicals and processes such as printing ink, paint stripping solutions, refrigerants, permanent wave solutions.

Liming: liming and scaling covered in detail in Water heaters and combination systems unit.

Underfiring and overfiring: important for efficient system operation to maintain proper boiler firing rate. Boiler firing rate specified on rating plate. Underfiring not necessarily problem if boiler and venting system designed to allow for lesser input. However this means boiler not operating at full level of efficiency and flue-gas temperatures may be low. Overfiring boiler can result in problems such as incomplete combustion and excessively high flue-gas (or stack) temperatures. When boiler overfiring check input by clocking gas meter. If input incorrect check manifold pressure and adjust it or change burner orifice size.

Mechanical problems: mechanical malfunctions can cause problems such as insufficient heat in one or more rooms or zones or throughout building and noise in system. Insufficient heat output generally result of insufficient or no flow in system and incorrect temperature settings. These can in turn be cause of number of faults including faulty or misadjusted manual isolation, zone, check, mixing, or balancing valves, lack of pressure (insufficient head pressure), air or air locks in system, undersized or scaled piping, and incorrect temperature settings on mixing valves.

Table 4-1 shows mechanical system problems and possible causes. Problems include insufficient heat throughout building during periods of cold weather (limit set below system design temperature, airflow restricted to radiation equipment), boiler fires but cycles on/off on limit control (radiation equipment inadequately sized, pumping or flow restriction problem), no heat in upper floor of building (air in system due to problem with water feed regulator), one cold radiator manual air bleed (air locked, needs to be purged), gurgling sound in pipes manual air bleed (air bubbles, requirement to shut down pump and bleed all radiators, advise customer to repeat process regularly), circulator making loud rattling noise (requirement to check for broken pump coupler or pump cavitation), flow switch keeps boiler burner from firing but activates when shaken (pump size incorrect, line restriction, incorrect installation of flow switch in relation to pipe size and fittings, incorrect installation of flow switch sensing paddles).

Noise in system: noise can result from several conditions such as air in system (producing gurgling noises), zone valves installed backwards (cause water hammer when slam shut), undersized pumps or pumps operating at excessive rpm (causing increased flow velocity which creates noise in system), poorly secured piping supports (can cause noisy vibrations), inadequate expansion and contraction clearances between piping and building structure (may result in noise when piping rubs against structure), and pump cavitation can be major source of noise.

Pump cavitation: formation of bubbles in liquid through pressure variation, heating, or vibration. Pump cavitation characterized by gurgling or popping sounds, vibration, and erratic flow. Can reduce or eliminate pump cavitation in hydronic system by keeping system static pressure as high as possible, keeping system fluid temperature as low as possible, positioning expansion tank as near to inlet of pump as possible, installing pump at as low point in system as possible (to increase static pressure at pump inlet), installing pipe leading to pump inlet as straight run at least ten pipe diameters in length, equipping system with adequate air removal devices, and placing high-head or multiple pump installations (to ensure greater pressure differentials produced do not cause cavitation).

For in-ground pools drain incorporating hydro-relief valve for admitting water to empty pool recommended
If groundwater pressure below pool, hydro relief valve opens allowing groundwater to enter pool
Operating and safety controls (in addition to pressure switch acting as safety device)
Thermostat (aquastat): most pool heaters have mechanical aquastat mounted on heater unit
Can adjust aquastat (usually maximum setting 100 °F/38 °C) to desired water temperature
Aquastat cycles heater on and off as required to maintain desired water temperature
Can leave aquastat at desired setting and use on-off switch to shut heater off when not required
High-limit aquastat: all pool heaters must have high-limit aquastat to limit water temperature to 140 °F (60 °C) to prevent scalding
Usually installed in heat exchanger outlet header
If outlet water temperature exceeds 140 °F aquastat switches heater off
Pilot safety: two types of pilot safety devices used (self-energizing millivolt and electronic ignition)
Millivolt system: thermopile or pilot generator produces electrical current operating gas valve
Type of pilot system also functions as safety device
If pilot flame extinguished thermopile cools off opening electrical circuit to de-energize gas valve and shut down gas flow
Relight pilot burner manually before operating heater
Electronic ignition: automatically lights heater burner pilot upon receiving demand for heat from thermostat
Main gas valve does not open until pilot flame proven
When desired temperature reached ignition system automatically shuts off gas flow extinguishing burner and pilot flames
System sizing (calculations to determine proper size of components)
Pool heater sizing, gas pipe sizing, vent sizing, pump sizing, filter sizing
Pool heater sizing: sized according to surface area of pool and difference between desired pool temperature and average local air temperature
Surface area used instead of water volume (pools with same surface area have approximately same volume)
Surface area also takes heating effect of direct sunlight into account
1 Btu amount of heat required to raise temperature of 1 lb water by 1 °F
Raising 1 imp gal (10 lb) water by 1 °F requires 10 Btu
With volume of pool and temperature rise of heater can determine size of heater required
Simple procedure: calculate area of pool surface in ft², identify temperature desired for water
Determine average temperature for coldest month of pool use
Subtract coldest month average temperature from desired pool temperature to get required temperature rise
Formula: Heater output (Btu/h) ÷ I = Pool area (ft²) × Temperature rise (°F) × 12
Metric: Heater output (kW) ÷ I = Pool area (m²) × Temperature rise (°C) × 0.07
Formula based on temperature rise 1 to 1.25 °F per hour (0.55 to 0.7 °C per hour) and average wind speed 3.5 mph (5.8 kph)
Factors affecting pool heating load: exposure to sun and wind, relative humidity, cooler nighttime temperatures
Pools in areas with higher-than-average wind speeds, low humidity, and cool nights require larger heaters
Example based on pool with average depth 5.5 ft (1.66 m): 40 ft × 20 ft = 800 ft², 800 × 15 °F rise × 12 = 144 MBtu/h
Gas pipe sizing: conforms with normal pipe sizing procedures
Vent sizing: materials and other installation requirements specified in pool heater manufacturer instructions
In all cases venting must conform to all applicable codes
Pump sizing: covered in detail in Chapter 2, includes filter type, filter flow rate, and pool water turnover time
Follow manufacturer requirements for pool pumping systems
Filter sizing: based on filter type and flow rate, and pool water turnover time
Filter type and flow rate: filters classified according to filter media
Flow rate differs for each type of filter media, measured in US gpm per ft² of filter area
Diatomaceous earth 1 to 2 US gpm (0.065 to 0.126 L/s)
Rapid sand 3 to 5 US gpm (0.189 to 0.315 L/s)
High-rate sand 15 to 20 US gpm (0.945 to 1.26 L/s)
Fabric cartridge 0.5 to 1 US gpm (0.031 to 0.063 L/s)
Turnover time: length of time in hours required to circulate all water in pool once through filter
Determining filter size: Filter rate = pool capacity (in US gal) ÷ (turnover time × 60)
Filter area = filter rate ÷ flow rate
From manufacturer catalogue select size and number of filters required to match filter area
Cleaning and winterizing (regular cleaning of heat exchanger tubes and preparation of pool equipment for winter)
Cleaning heat exchanger tubes: inside surfaces vulnerable to scale accumulation
Soot from incomplete combustion and corrosion products can accumulate on exterior surfaces
Exterior of tubes: in most cases remove soot and corrosion using wire brush
May also use high-velocity water spray if heat exchanger removed from heater
Using water to clean while in place may damage combustion chamber and heater insulation
Interior of tubes: clean in two ways (acid cleaning or reaming)
Must always follow proper WHMIS and other recommended procedures and use necessary PPE
Acid cleaning (use extreme caution): remove heat exchanger tube assembly from heater per manufacturer instructions
Immerse tube assembly in solution of three parts water to one part muriatic acid
Observe action of acid solution on tube assembly, when tubes appear clean remove from acid solution
Thoroughly rinse assembly with soda-ash solution then with clean water
Let assembly dry thoroughly then apply heat-resistant rust-inhibiting paint per manufacturer instructions
Reassemble heat exchanger and heater
Dispose of acid and soda-ash solutions per WHMIS and applicable environmental regulations
Reaming: remove heat exchanger tube assembly from heater per manufacturer instructions
Thoroughly dry heat exchanger (makes tubes easier to ream out)
Measure inside diameter of tubes and select carbide-tipped reamer of same diameter
Ream inside of tubes, frequently remove reamer to clear powdered scale and debris and prevent binding
After reaming completed blow or rinse tubes clean, reassemble heat exchanger and heater
Winterizing: when pool not used during winter months must be winterized
Generally includes draining all water from pool heater, circulation equipment, and piping system
Removing or weatherproofing electrical and mechanical equipment that can be damaged by exposure to winter conditions
Closing off pool and equipment openings to prevent accumulation of debris and provide protection from rain and snow
Draining system: open all drain valves, remove all drain plugs, allow as much water as possible to drain by gravity
Any water left in system can be blown out via compressed air or inert gases
Important to ensure no water left in heat exchanger of pool heater
Even during short periods of freezing temperatures stagnant water in exchanger tubes can form ice which expands and splits tubes
If water remains in pool equipment and piping during below-freezing conditions, freezes and expands splitting pipes and damaging equipment
Caution when igniting burner of pool heater for first time in season
Pool heaters more dangerous than other types of boilers (spiders or other creatures may crawl into burner throats and pilot heads)
Difficult with pool heater to hear burner gas flowing or click of millivolt valve over sound of nearby pump
Troubleshooting burner and ignition system (Table 5-1 outlines common problems, causes, and solutions)
Delayed ignition (corroded burner due to system fluid leakage, accumulated debris, materials blocking airflow, inadequate gas flow to pilot or misalignment)
Heater not operating (no gas flow, main gas valve turned off, pilot extinguished, no electrical power, pool water temperature higher than thermostat setting)
Pump not operating or lost prime, dirty filter
Pilot not lighting or remaining lit (no gas at pilot burner, weak pilot generator, draft extinguishes pilot, condensation extinguishes pilot, soot accumulation)
Slow heater output (air in system, filter pump too small, heater too small, limit control set too low, low pressure in system)
Heater not shutting off (defective gas valve, short circuit)
Heater short cycles (high-limit switch set too low, low water flow due to heat exchanger scaling or manual bypass valve open too far)
Air leak in suction line, incorrect pressure switch setting, weak pilot generator, gas pressure too high or too low
Hot spot in heater, insufficient combustion air
Noise in system (air in system, filter pump too large, inadequate piping support, low water pressure or flow, pump coupler broken, faulty pump impeller or bearing)
Excessive soot accumulation (too little or too much gas, poor draft conditions, condensation on heat exchanger, heater not properly levelled)
Insufficient combustion air, debris on heat exchanger or blocking flue vent, draft hood of incorrect length, incorrect burner assembly, leaking heat exchanger
Purpose of lint trap (or strainer) in pool system: protects pump
To remove accumulated debris in sand filter must backwash
Normal differential setting for pool heater pressure switch: 2 psig (14 kPa)
Function of pool heater pressure switch: protects boiler from damage
Maximum setting for pool boiler operating aquastat: 100 °F (38 °C)
Maximum setting for pool boiler high-limit aquastat: 140 °F (60 °C)
Muriatic acid used to chemically clean inside surfaces of pool boiler heat exchanger tubes
Recommended flow rate for high-rate sand used for pool filter: 15 to 20 US gpm
When flow rate through pool system greater than 125 US gpm, manual bypass required between heater inlet and outlet pipes
Chlorine should be added to pool circulating system downstream of heater

Chapter 5 covers pool heating systems including components, sizing, cleaning, and troubleshooting. Pool heating and circulation system components shown in Figure 5-1 include backwashing valve, filter, heater, manual bypass valve if present, clean water to pool inlets, pool, skimmer, from pool drain, from skimmer, balancing valves, lint trap, pump, check valve, and pressure switch.

Piping runs: water circulates continuously through system in directions arrows indicate (however water does not flow in all pipes at same time).

Heater bypass valve: manual bypass valve shown between heater's inlet and outlet pipes. Bypass valve ensures proper flow through heater. Manual bypass required on systems with flow rate more than 125 US gpm (8 L/s). On some systems with flow rates less than 125 US gpm manual bypass not required. Automatic bypass valve built into some pool heaters. Function of bypass valve is to reduce condensation by allowing water to bypass fin-tube coil when pump rates high. Operation depends on spring-loaded valve seat opening when pressure behind valve reaches critical point. This causes cold water to bypass heater coil keeping coil warmer.

Pressure switch (or heater actuator): turns heater off and on. Pressure switch only switches heater on when filter pump running to ensure adequate flow through heater. Pressure switch senses water flow in circulation piping when pump starts up then activates heater, normally component within pool heater and typically set to 2 psig (14 kPa), prevents damage to fin tube resulting from low or no water flow through heater (if heater operated without proper circulation, water in heat exchanger would quickly boil off resulting in damage to unit). Can adjust setting of pressure switch to compensate for different water levels in pool.

Testing pool heater pressure switch procedure: raise temperature control to maximum setting, confirm burner lights, turn gas valve to pilot position, turn off power to pump (or restrict water flow), turn gas valve to on position, confirm main burner does not light, restore power to pump or restore water flow, observe main burner lights, return temperature control to original setting.

Filter pump: in basic pool recirculation system filter pump draws water from pool through drain and skimmer, water then passes through filter and into pool heater, at chlorinator necessary chemicals added to heated water and water flows back into pool. Filter pump provides all pressure required to maintain water flow through recirculation system. Pump works by centrifugal action.

Valves: installed in pool piping system perform variety of functions. Some filter pumps have built-in check valve in front of strainer. If pump located above water level of pool, check valve prevents water from draining from suction pipe when strainer opened. When pump does not have check valve install gate valve in suction line to prevent draining. Install gate valve in pool return piping to prevent draining of strainer due to siphoning through filter. Proper placing of valves in pool piping system ensures system remains full of water and does not require repriming after maintenance.

Filter: water flows downwards through filter bed where dirt and debris collect in sand filter. As dirt accumulates in filter bed, water flow through it gradually restricted. Eventually cleaning filter bed requires backwashing (or flushing). Backwashing basically reversal of flow path through filter bed to wash accumulated debris out of system.

Skimmer: mounted in wall of pool at water level and connected directly to filter pump suction piping between drain and pump. Vacuum created by skimmer's suction action pulls in water from pool's surface layer removing floating dust, debris, leaves, and any oil film accumulated on surface. This prevents accumulation of deposits on bottom and walls of pool.

Strainers: screens preventing large pieces of debris from damaging pump and creating blockages in system. Installed at skimmer and filter pump inlets.

Drain and hydro-relief valve: drain valve located on filter pump suction piping connected to drain at bottom of pool. Opened to drain pool for maintenance purposes. For in-ground pools drain incorporating hydro-relief valve for admitting water to empty pool recommended. This because if groundwater pressure below pool, hydro relief valve opens allowing groundwater to enter pool (rather than pushing against bottom of pool).

Operating and safety controls: in addition to pressure switch acting as safety device, pool heater system has following operating and safety controls.

Thermostat (aquastat): most pool heaters have mechanical aquastat mounted on heater unit. Can adjust aquastat (usually maximum setting 100 °F/38 °C) to desired water temperature. Aquastat cycles heater on and off as required to maintain desired water temperature in pool. Can leave aquastat at desired setting and use on-off switch to shut heater off when not required.

High-limit aquastat: all pool heaters must have high-limit aquastat to limit water temperature to 140 °F (60 °C) to prevent scalding. Usually installed in heat exchanger outlet header. If outlet water temperature exceeds 140 °F aquastat switches heater off.

Pilot safety: two types of pilot safety devices used in pool heating systems (self-energizing millivolt and electronic ignition). Millivolt system: thermopile or pilot generator produces electrical current operating gas valve. Type of pilot system also functions as safety device. If pilot flame extinguished thermopile cools off opening electrical circuit to de-energize gas valve and shut down gas flow to pilot and heater burner. If this occurs relight pilot burner manually before operating heater. Electronic ignition: automatically lights heater burner pilot upon receiving demand for heat from thermostat. Main gas valve does not open until pilot flame proven. When desired temperature reached ignition system automatically shuts off gas flow extinguishing burner and pilot flames.

System sizing: requires calculations to determine proper size of components (pool heater, gas pipe, vent, pump, filter).

Pool heater sizing: sized according to surface area of pool and difference between desired pool temperature and average local air temperature. Surface area used instead of water volume (pools with same surface area have approximately same volume and surface area also takes heating effect of direct sunlight into account). Remember 1 Btu is amount of heat required to raise temperature of 1 lb water by 1 °F. Therefore raising 1 imp gal (10 lb) water by 1 °F requires 10 Btu. With volume of pool and temperature rise of heater can determine size of heater required.

Simple procedure for sizing pool heater: calculate area of pool surface in ft², identify temperature desired for water in pool, determine average temperature for coldest month of pool use (information available from local weather service office), subtract coldest month average temperature from desired pool temperature to get required temperature rise, use formula: Heater output (Btu/h) ÷ I = Pool area (ft²) × Temperature rise (°F) × 12 or Heater output (kW) ÷ I = Pool area (m²) × Temperature rise (°C) × 0.07. Formula based on temperature rise 1 to 1.25 °F per hour (0.55 to 0.7 °C per hour) and average wind speed 3.5 mph (5.8 kph) at pool surface. Factors such as exposure to sun and wind, relative humidity, cooler nighttime temperatures affect pool's heating load. Pools located in areas with higher-than-average wind speeds, low humidity, and cool nights require larger heaters. Example based on pool with average depth 5.5 ft (1.66 m): 40 ft × 20 ft = 800 ft², 800 × 15 °F temperature rise × 12 = 144 MBtu/h.

Gas pipe sizing: conforms with normal pipe sizing procedures. Vent sizing: materials and other installation requirements specified in pool heater manufacturer instructions. In all cases venting must conform to all applicable codes. Pump sizing: covered in detail in Chapter 2, includes filter type, filter flow rate, and pool water turnover time. Follow manufacturer requirements for pool pumping systems.

Filter sizing: based on filter type and flow rate, and pool water turnover time. Filter type and flow rate: filters classified according to filter media. Flow rate differs for each type measured in US gpm per ft² of filter area. Diatomaceous earth 1 to 2 US gpm (0.065 to 0.126 L/s), rapid sand 3 to 5 US gpm (0.189 to 0.315 L/s), high-rate sand 15 to 20 US gpm (0.945 to 1.26 L/s), fabric cartridge 0.5 to 1 US gpm (0.031 to 0.063 L/s). Turnover time: length of time in hours required to circulate all water in pool once through filter. Determining filter size: Filter rate = pool capacity (in US gal) ÷ (turnover time × 60), Filter area = filter rate ÷ flow rate, from manufacturer catalogue select size and number of filters required to match filter area.

Cleaning and winterizing: regular cleaning of heat exchanger tubes and preparation of pool equipment for winter important for pool heater maintenance and service. Cleaning heat exchanger tubes: inside surfaces vulnerable to scale accumulation. Soot from incomplete combustion and corrosion products can accumulate on exterior surfaces.

Exterior of tubes: in most cases remove soot and corrosion on exterior surfaces using wire brush. May also use high-velocity water spray if heat exchanger removed from heater. Using water to clean heat exchanger while in place may damage combustion chamber and heater insulation.

Interior of tubes: clean in two ways (acid cleaning or reaming). Technicians/fitters must always follow proper WHMIS and other recommended procedures and use necessary PPE.

Acid cleaning (use extreme caution): remove heat exchanger tube assembly from heater per manufacturer instructions, immerse tube assembly in solution of three parts water to one part muriatic acid, observe action of acid solution on tube assembly (when tubes appear clean remove assembly from acid solution), thoroughly rinse assembly with soda-ash solution then with clean water, let assembly dry thoroughly then apply heat-resistant rust-inhibiting paint per manufacturer instructions, reassemble heat exchanger and heater, dispose of acid and soda-ash solutions per WHMIS and applicable environmental regulations.

Reaming: remove heat exchanger tube assembly from heater per manufacturer instructions, thoroughly dry heat exchanger (makes tubes easier to ream out), measure inside diameter of tubes and select carbide-tipped reamer of same diameter, ream inside of tubes (frequently remove reamer to clear powdered scale and debris and prevent binding), after reaming completed blow or rinse tubes clean, reassemble heat exchanger and heater.

Winterizing: in situations when pool not used during winter months must be winterized. Generally includes draining all water from pool heater, circulation equipment, and piping system, removing or weatherproofing electrical and mechanical equipment that can be damaged by exposure to winter conditions, and closing off pool and equipment openings to prevent accumulation of debris and provide protection from rain and snow.

Draining system: open all drain valves, remove all drain plugs, allow as much water as possible to drain from system by way of gravity, any water left in system can be blown out via compressed air or inert gases. Important to ensure no water left in heat exchanger of pool heater. Even during short periods of freezing temperatures stagnant water in exchanger tubes can form ice which expands and splits tubes. If water remains in pool equipment and piping during below-freezing conditions, freezes and expands splitting pipes and damaging equipment.

Caution: take care when igniting burner of pool heater for first time in season. Pool heaters more dangerous than other types of boilers because spiders or other creatures may crawl into burner throats and pilot heads. Also difficult with pool heater to hear burner gas flowing or click of millivolt valve over sound of nearby pump.

Troubleshooting burner and ignition system: Table 5-1 outlines common pool heater burner and ignition problems, causes, and solutions. Problems include delayed ignition (corroded burner, accumulated debris, materials blocking airflow, inadequate gas flow to pilot or misalignment), heater not operating (no gas flow, main gas valve off, pilot extinguished, no electrical power, pool water temperature higher than thermostat setting, pump not operating or lost prime, dirty filter), pilot not lighting or remaining lit (no gas at pilot burner, weak pilot generator, draft extinguishes pilot, condensation extinguishes pilot, soot accumulation), slow heater output (air in system, filter pump too small, heater too small, limit control set too low, low pressure in system), heater not shutting off (defective gas valve, short circuit), heater short cycles (high-limit switch set too low, low water flow due to heat exchanger scaling or manual bypass valve open too far, air leak in suction line, incorrect pressure switch setting, weak pilot generator, gas pressure too high or too low, hot spot in heater, insufficient combustion air), noise in system (air in system, filter pump too large, inadequate piping support, low water pressure or flow, pump coupler broken, faulty pump impeller or bearing), excessive soot accumulation (too little or too much gas, poor draft conditions, condensation on heat exchanger, heater not properly levelled, insufficient combustion air, debris on heat exchanger or blocking flue vent, draft hood of incorrect length, incorrect burner assembly, leaking heat exchanger).

CSA Unit 20 - Hydronic 
Heating Systems
Chapter 1                                         
Boilers: Understanding 
Hydronic Heating Systems
A gas-fired boiler transfers the heat produced from the combustion of 
the gas to the water contained in the boiler. It is important that the gas 
technician/fitter know the proper procedures for mounting and installing 
gas-fired boilers and their components as a major subsystem of hydronic 
space heating systems.
MK by Mike Kapin
Created
Copywrite 2025
Hydronic Heating System Overview
Purpose
A gas-fired boiler transfers the heat 
produced from the combustion of the 
gas to the water contained in the 
boiler. This heated water is then 
distributed throughout a building to 
provide space heating.
Objectives
•
Describe hydronic heating systems
•
Describe hydronic heating system 
boilers
•
Describe boiler components
Key Terminology
Term
Definition
Hydronic space heating system
Uses water to transfer thermal 
energy from the source to its 
point(s) of use
Spillage
When there is no draft, a 
backdraft, or a blockage 
beyond the draft hood, the flue 
gases exit the draft-hood 
instead of enter the appliance
Introduction to Hydronic 
Heating
Heat Transfer
A space heating system 
moves thermal energy 
(heat) from a heat source to 
the space(s) to be heated.
Hydronics
Hydronics involves the 
heating and cooling of 
spaces using liquids as the 
heat transfer medium.
Temperature Range
Hydronic systems use water only in its liquid state, over a practical 
temperature range of 50 to 250°F (10 to 121 °C).
Evolution of Hydronic Systems
Early Systems
Early hydronic systems relied on the natural convection created 
by hot rising water and cool descending water streams for 
distribution and circulation in the system piping.
Modern Systems
Through the use of technology, modern hydronic heating 
systems are able to distribute heat exactly where and when it is 
required to maintain desired temperature levels.
Future Developments
Continued advancements in efficiency, control systems, and 
integration with renewable energy sources.
Scope of Gas Technician's Work
Provincial Regulations
Gas technicians/fitters are limited 
in the scope of work that they may 
perform in areas covered by other 
trades. This may vary from province 
to province since the gas 
technician's/fitter's responsibilities 
and limitations are governed by 
provincial regulations.
Ontario Example
Ontario regulations state that a gas 
technician/fitter must not perform 
any work beyond the gas side of a 
hydronic system unless the gas 
technician/fitter also holds a 
certificate of qualification issued 
under the Trades Qualification and 
Apprenticeship Act as a plumber or 
steamfitter.
Permitted Work
"Disconnect and reconnect water 
piping in order to exchange, service 
or install an approved appliance and 
carry out the replacement of water 
pipe necessary to complete the 
reconnection or controls, control 
systems, components and 
accessories that are essential to the 
operation of the appliance."
Hydronic Subsystems
Heat Source
Usually a boiler or hot water heater
Distribution System
Piping, valves, and circulators
Heat Emitters
Baseboard convector unit, wall-mounted radiators, or radiant floors
Control System
Thermostats, aquastats, controllers, switches, relays
Advantages of Hydronic Heating 
Systems
Energy Efficiency
Many studies have consistently shown lower heating energy use than equivalent 
structures with forced air heating and similar ducted heating systems.
Clean, Quiet Operation
When a hydronic system operates properly, it is silent in comparison to the noise of 
airflow through ducts and outlets.
Increased Comfort Levels
One big advantage of heating through radiation is that surfaces in rooms tend to be 
warmer. This reduces the effect of radiant heat loss from the body and increases 
comfort.
Zoning Capability
A hydronic system can have as many areas of control (called zones). A forced air system 
typically has one thermostat location.
More Advantages of 
Hydronic Heating
Design Flexibility
Hydronic heating offers 
almost unlimited 
possibilities to 
accommodate space 
heating, domestic water 
heating, snow melting, and 
pool heating.
Less Air Stratification
Stratification is the 
tendency of warm air to rise 
and accumulate at the 
ceiling while cold air falls 
and gathers at the floor. 
Hydronic systems reduce 
this effect.
Fewer Contaminants
Hydronic systems do not circulate as much dust and pollen 
through the air as do forced air systems.
Disadvantages of Hydronic 
Heating Systems
Installation Cost
A forced air system is on average 
less costly to install than a 
hydronic system.
Reaction Time
A forced air system is quicker to 
respond to temperature 
demands in a room due to its 
lower thermal mass than a 
hydronic system using 
convectors or radiant panels.
Heat Emitter Intrusion
Aside from radiant floor, wall, and ceiling panels, the heat transfer units 
used in hydronic heating might interfere with the aesthetics of a room. 
Freestanding radiators and convectors can affect the placement of 
furniture and drapes among other things.
Hydronic Heating System Boilers
Purpose
In a hydronic space heating system, 
the purpose of a boiler is to heat the 
water. A gas-fired boiler transfers the 
heat produced from the combustion 
of the water contained in the boiler.
Operation
The hot water circulates through the 
hydronic system piping to space 
heating units where it gives up its heat 
to the building before returning to the 
boiler to be reheated.
Installation Requirements
Code Compliance
Section 7 of CSA B149.1 
includes installation 
requirements for propane-
fired and natural gas-fired 
boilers.
Provincial Regulations
Boilers must also conform 
to the requirements of the 
applicable provincial Boiler 
and Pressure Vessel 
Regulations.
Permits
Ensure that when 
applicable, permits have 
been applied for before 
starting any work.
Manufacturer 
Instructions
Review and implement 
manufacturer's installation 
instructions in all boiler 
installations.
Mounting Bases and Clearances
Firm and Level Base
Mounting of a boiler must be on a firm and 
level base. The floor or supporting surface 
must be non-combustible, except where 
the boiler is certified for installation on a 
combustible surface.
Combustible Surface Installation
A boiler that does not yet have a 
certification for installation on a 
combustible floor may only be installed on 
combustible surfaces if one of the following 
conditions is met:
•
A base designed by the boiler 
manufacturer is used; or
•
The boiler (up to 400 MBtu/h /120 kW) 
is mounted on a platform that extends 6 
inches (150 mm) beyond the edge of 
the boiler and is made of two rows of 4 
inch (100 cm) block laid sideways and 
covered with a piece of sheet metal with 
a minimum thickness of 0.0195 inch 
(0.56 mm).
Clearances
Maintaining clearances between the boiler 
and combustible materials is a must, as 
specified in applicable Codes and the 
manufacturer's installation instructions.
Piping Specifications
Sizing
Sizing of near boiler piping and supply and return piping 
must be in accordance with approved trade practices
Code Compliance
All piping must comply with applicable Codes
Manufacturer Instructions
Follow equipment manufacturer's instructions for proper 
installation
Cross-Contamination, 
Overpressure, and Low Water 
Hazards
Backflow Prevention
Hydronic system boilers 
require installation of valves 
to prevent backflow (cross-
contamination) between 
potable water and non-
potable boiler water.
Overpressure 
Protection
Safety relief valves are 
required to protect against 
dangerous pressure buildup 
in the system.
Low Water Protection
Low water cut-off devices prevent the boiler from operating when 
water levels are insufficient, which could cause damage or unsafe 
conditions.
Backflow Prevention
Air Gap Device 
(AG)
Physical separation 
between potable 
water supply and non-
potable water
Dual Check with 
Atmospheric Port 
(DCAP)
Prevents backflow 
with atmospheric 
venting capability
Double Check 
Valve Assembly 
(DCVA)
Two independent 
check valves in series
Reduced 
Pressure 
Principle (RP)
Provides maximum 
protection against 
backflow
A qualified individual must install, test, and maintain the backflow prevention device. This will typically be a Red Seal Plumber or 
Steamfitter/Pipefitter with additional backflow certification subject to approval by the authority having jurisdiction.
Overpressure Protection
Safety Relief Valve Requirements
•
Comply with all applicable Code requirements, including 
temperature and pressure ratings
•
Be certified as the proper type and capacity for the application
•
Be equipped with a try-lever for testing
Installation Requirements
•
Be installed in the proper location on the boiler as per 
manufacturer's instructions
•
Be protected from the effects of lime or scale buildup
•
Be piped according to local Code requirements
Low Water Safety Control
Purpose
A low water level in a boiler can result 
in damage to the boiler and/or an 
unsafe condition, especially if the 
boiler is fired when it is dry or nearly 
dry.
Code Requirements
It is a Code requirement that all steam 
boilers have at least one automatic
